chapter.title: Setting User Preferences
chapter.para: User preferences control a number of aspects of program execution and contain many text and QSOs Box related properties. Depending on some of the user preferences settings, HamQSLer may save additional information in the user preferences file. For example, if the setting for restoring ADIF files is set, then the paths to all ADIF files that were loaded would be saved with the user preferences so that HamQSLer could load these files when the program starts.

User preferences are written to a text file called .hamqsler and stored in the hamqsler directory. This file is loaded during program initialization. See the Program Initialization and the Splash Screen chapter for more information.

Users edit user preferences settings by using the User Preferences dialog. This dialog is displayed by selecting the Edit->User Preferences menu item on the main window. When first opened, the dialog looks like the image below.

figure.title: User Preferences Dialog When First Opened

chapter.para: User preferences are arranged in a set of topics. For example, Program contains settings that affect how HamQSLer executes, and TextItems contains settings related to text items. The default font face for text items and the default callsign, name and QTH, and salutation that are placed on a card when it is first created are examples of texit item settings.

The box on the left of the dialog contains the set of topics in expander controls. To open an expander, either click on the arrowhead to the left of the topic, or double-click on the topic name. The image below shows the topics with all expanders opened.
Clicking on any of the subtopics displays a panel of controls on the right side of the dialog. These controls may be set by the user to changed the corresponding user preference.
Each of the topics and settings is discussed in the sections that follow.

section.title: Program Settings
section.para: Program settings affect the execution of HamQSLer during program initialization.

section.title: Program Version Check
section.para: The image below shows the user preferences dialog with the Program Version Check subtopic selected. There are only two settings, one for checking for new versions of the program and data files, and one for also checking for new development releases.

The Check for Program and Data File Updates checkbox controls whether HamQSLer checks for new program and data file versions during initialization. With the checkbox checked, the program checks for new versions, and with the checkbox unchecked, the program does not check for new versions. The default value (the value set when the user preferences file is first created) is to check for new versions.

The Stable and Development Program Releases checkbox determines whether HamQSLer should check only for data file updates and stable program updates, or if it should also check for development updates. if this checkbox is checked, then HamQSLer checks for both stable and development new releases during program initialization. If unchecked, HamQSLer checks only for new stable releases. The default value is to not check for development versions.

Development versions of HamQSLer are provided to allow users access to new features as they are developed rather than waiting for a stable release. You can think of development releases as beta releases of the program.
This checkbox can only be checked or unchecked if the Check for Program and Data File Updates checkbox is checked.

tip.para: Development releases give users access to new features as they are being developed rather than waiting for the final release.

caution.para: Development releases have not necessarily been tested as thoroughly as stable releases, so more bugs may be encountered in a development release that its subsequent stable release. Of course, if no one uses the development release, then the bugs won't be found until the stable release.

section.title: HTTP Proxy Settings
section.para: The image below shows the user preferences dialog with the HTTP Proxy Settings subtopic selected. These controls configure HamQSLer to use an HTTP proxy. Most users do not need to modify the default settings.
The proxy server control is used to specify the name or IP address of the HTTP proxy server. The default value is no server.
The proxy server port is the port number for the HTTP proxy server. The default value is 80, which is the standard port number for HTTP servers. Other typical port numbers are 8000, 8080, and 8888.

caution.para: Change these settings only if HamQSLer cannot retrieve the versions file during program initialization. Internet service providers typically do not require you to configure proxy servers on their networks, so proxy server settings are only required if your network has one installed. This is not something that is typically done on a home network.
Even if a proxy server is installed on your network, it would normally be configured in Control Panel->Internet Options, so there would be no need to configure the server here.

section.title: Files and Folders
section.para: These user preferences subtopics contain preferences related to ADIF, card, and images files and folders.

section.title: ADIF Files and Folder
section.para: This subtopic contains preferences specifying whether HamQSLer should reload ADIF files when the program starts, and the directory that the file open dialog should open in when handling Import QSOs... and Add QSOs... menu items processing. The image below shows the user preferences dialog with the ADIF Files and Folder subtopic selected.

The Reload ADIF Files on Startup checkbox setting determines whether ADIF files are reloaded or not when HamQSLer starts up. With the checkbox checked, the files are loaded; with the checkbox unchecked, the files are not loaded.
The files that are reloaded are determined by the user's use of four menu items from the QSOs dropdown menu:

listitem.para: Selecting the Clear QSOs menu item also clears the ADIF files reload list.
Selecting the Import QSOs... menu item clears the ADIF files reload list, and then adds the the newly selected ADIF file to the list.
Selecting the Add QSOs... menu item adds the newly selected ADIF file to the list.
Selecting the Export QSOs... menu item clears the ADIF files list and then add the file to which the QSOs were exported to the list.

section.para: The ADIF files list is stored in the user preferences file but there is no way for the user to see the list except by opening the user preferences file in a text editor.

caution.para: If the user opens the user preferences file in a text editor, he must be certain not to make any changes to the file; in other words, if a change is made accidentally, the user must not save the file. Editing the user preferences file could result in HamQSLer aborting or otherwise malfunctioning.

section.para: The Default ADIF Files Folder is the directory that HamQSLer opens in a File Open dialog when the user selects either the Import QSOs... or Add QSOs... menu item. The user should set this value to the directory in which he stores ADIF files.
To change the folder, click on the button labeled "..." that is located to the right of the folder name. This opens a Folder Browser dialog from which the user may select a new directory.

section.title: Cards Files and Folder Preferences
section.para: This subtopic contains preferences specifying whether HamQSLer should reload card files when the program starts, and the directory that the file open dialog should open in when handling the Open Card... menu item processing. The image below shows the user preferences dialog with the Card Files and Folder subtopic selected.

The Reload Card Files on Startup checkbox setting determines whether card files are reloaded or not when HamQSLer starts up. With the checkbox checked, the files are loaded; with the checkbox unchecked, the files are not loaded.
The files that are reloaded are determined by the card files that are open when HamQSLer is terminated. New cards that have not been saved are not reloaded.
The card files list is stored in the user preferences file but there is no way for the user to see the list except by opening the user preferences file in a text editor.

caution.para: If you open the user preferences file in a text editor, be certain not to make any changes to the file; in other words, if a change is made accidentally, do not save the file. Editing the user preferences file could result in HamQSLer aborting or otherwise malfunctioning.

section.para: The Default Card Files Folder is the directory that HamQSLer opens in a File Open dialog when the user selects the OpenCard menu item. The user should set this value to the directory in which he stores ADIF files.
To change the folder, click on the button labeled "..." that is located to the right of the folder name. This opens a Folder Browser dialog from which the user may select a new directory.

section.title: Images Folder Preferences
section.para: This subtopic contains a single preference, the default images folder. This specifies the directory that the file open dialog is opened in when the user adds a background or secondary image to the card in design mode.

The image above shows the user preferences dialog with the Images Folder subtopic selected. To change the directory, click on the button labeled ... to the right of the folder name. This opens the Folder Browser dialog from which the user may select a new directory.

section.title: Text Items Preferences
section.para: The text items topic contains user preferences that are related to text items in general and the default callsign, name and QTH, and salutation texts that are added to a new card when it is created.

section.title: Default Text Font Preference
section.para: The default text font is the font that text items are displayed in when a new card is created. All text items are displayed in this font on the new card. However, the user may later select a different font for each text item on the card. See the Working With Cards chapter for more information.

The user preferences dialog with the default font face subtopic selected is shown in the image below. The only preference available in this panel is the Default Text FontFace. A list of all fonts registered on the computer is provided in a dropdown box. When HamQSLer is executed for the first time, the default text font face is set to Arial.
Select the font you want as the default from the dropdown box. A sample of text in that font is displayed in the box below the dropdown box.

section.title: Default Callsign Text Preference
section.para: The default callsign text is the callsign that is placed on a new card when it is first created. The image below shows the user preferences dialog with the Callsign Text subtopic selected. In this image, there is a text box with the text "MyCall" in it, and a Macros button below it. When the user preferences file is created, either the first time that HamQSLer is started, or if HamQSLer cannot locate the user preferences files and creates a new one, the default callsign is set to "MyCall".
You may either edit the callsign text, or click on the Macros button to set the default callsign to a set of macros. See the Macros chapter for more information.

tip.para: If you always use the same callsign, change "MyCall" to that callsign. If you followed the Getting Started tutorial, then you have already performed this step.

If you use a number of different callsigns and the callsign that is used for each QSO is stored in your QSO database and exported to an ADIF file, then you should follow one of more of the tips in the AdifMacro and AdifExistsMacro sections of the Macros chapter. See the documentation for your logging program to determine the ADIF fields that the logging program uses.

section.title: Default Name and QTH Text Preference
section.para: The default name and QTH text is placed on a new card when it is first created. The image that follows this paragraph shows the user preferences dialog with the Name and QTH Text subtopic chosen. In this image, there is a text box with the text "MyQth" in it and a Macros button below it. When the user preferences file is first created, the default text is set to "MyQth".

figure.title: Default Name and QTH Text Preference

section.para: Change "MyQth" to your name and address. Use the Enter key to separate lines of text.
As an alternative, you could create a set of macros by clicking the Macros button, although it is unlikely to be very useful. Why would you want QSL cards sent to different addresses?

tip.para: If you operate from different locations such as at home, at your cottage, and as a rover during contests, add a new text item to the card and place the operating location in it. See Working With Cards for information about adding text items to a card.

section.title: Default Salutation Text Preference
section.para: The default salutation text is placed on a new card when it is first created. The first image below shows the user preferences dialog with the Salutation Text subtopic selected. Note that there is no text box, just a Macros button. This is what you would see the first time that you select this subtopic. There is no text box because the default salutation text contains macros, and therefore you must open the Static Text and Macros dialog by clicking on the Macros button to edit the salutation.

The image that follows shows the Static Text and Macros dialog box as it would appear if you have not edited the salutation before. Note that there is a Static Text group box with a text box containing the text "Thanks for the QSO" in it, a Count Macro group box, and finally, another Static Text group box with the text ". 73," in it. The count macro is discussed in the Macros chapter, so it will not be discussed in detail here.

As currently set up, the salutation text that is displayed on a new card in design mode is "Thanks for the QSO$. 73,". When you print cards, if you set the maximum number of QSOs that can be printed on a card to 1, or the maximum number of QSOs is set to greater than 1, but only one QSO is being printed on the card, then the salutation text that is printed is "Thanks for the QSO. 73,". If the maximum number of QSOs is set to greater than 1 and no QSOs are being printed or there is more than 1 QSO being printed on the card, then the salutation text printed on that card would be "Thanks for the QSOs. 73,".

tip.para: If you make changes to the count macro for this salutation, you may want to make similar changes to the confirming text preference in the QSOs Box Preferences, which is discussed below.

section.title: QSOs Box Preferences
section.para: The QSOs Box preferences topic contains user preferences that are related to the display of text items in the QSOs Box, such as the font face that all text in the QSOs Box is displayed in, the contents of the headers in each column of the box, and the frequency values printed for QSOs whose records contain a band field but no frequency field.

section.title: Default QSOs Box Font Preference
section.para: The default QSOs Box font is the font that all text in the QSOs Box is displayed in when a new card is created. While designing a card, the user may select a different font. See the Working With Cards chapter for more information.

The user preferences dialog with the default QSOs Box font face subtopic selected is shown in the image below. The only preference available in this panel is the Default QSOs Box FontFace. A list of all fonts registered on the computer is provided in a dropdown box. When HamQSLer is executed for the first time, the default QSOs Box font face is set to Arial.
Select the font you want as the default from the dropdown box. A sample of text in that font is displayed in the box below the dropdown box.

section.title: Confirming Text Preference
section.para: The confirming text is placed on the first line of the QSOs box of a card. The first image below shows the user preferences dialog with the Confirming Text subtopic selected. Note that there is no text box, just a Macros button. This is what you would see the first time that you select this subtopic. There is no text box because the default confirming text contains macros, and therefore you must open the Static Text and Macros dialog by clicking on the Macros button to edit the text.

The image that follows shows the Static Text and Macros dialog box as it would appear if you have not edited the confirming text before. Note that there is a Static Text group box with a text box containing the text "Confirming 2-Way QSO" in it, a Count Macro group box, and finally, another Static Text group box with the text "with" in it. The count macro is discussed in the Macros chapter, so it will not be discussed in detail here.

As currently set up, the confirming text that is displayed on a card in design mode is "Confirming 2-Way QSO$ with". When you print cards, if you set the maximum number of QSOs that can be printed on a card to 1, or the maximum number of QSOs is set to greater than 1, but only one QSO is being printed on the card, then the confiming text that is printed is "Confirming 2-Way QSO with". If the maximum number of QSOs is set to greater than 1 and no QSOs are being printed, or there is more than 1 QSO being printed on the card, then the salutation text printed on that card would be "Confirming 2-Way QSOs with".

tip.para: If you make changes to the count macro for this confirming text, you may want to make similar changes to the salutation text preference in the Text Items Preferences, which is discussed above.

section.title: Date Formats Preferences
section.para: These preferences refer to the format that dates should be printed in, and the header text for the date column in the QSOs Box.

The image above shows the user preferences dialog with the Date Formats subtopic selected. The dropdown box at the bottom of the panel contains all of the formats that the dates may be printed in. Currently the choices are:

listitem.para: YYYY-MM-DD. This is the date in ISO 8601 format.

section.para: Select the date format that you want to be the default date format when a new card is created. This may be changed to a different format when designing a card.
The choice of format determines the header text that is displayed in the date column in the QSOs Box. Edit the header text for each date format using the text boxes above the dropdown box.

tip.para: What does 02-04-03 mean? It depends on the country you live in, among other things. For the answer to this question and a discussion of meaningful date formats, see Use international date format.

caution.para: As noted in the tip above, 02-04-03 can mean different dates in different countries. If you do use DD-MM-YY as the date format on your card, do not change the header text to something like "Date" as this may bring back the confusion as to what the date actually is.

section.title: Header Text Preferences
section.para: This subtopic allows the user to set the header text for the Time, Band, Frequency, Mode, and RST columns.
The image below shows the user preferences dialog with the Header Text subtopic selected. There is one text box for each of the five headers.

Modify the header text to the text that you want for each column. The text may be a maximum of 6 characters. The header text for the QSOs Box on a card is fixed to these values when a card is creating. In other words, changing the preferences only affects new cards that the user creates.

caution.para: The values that are printed in the frequency column are in MHz, so don't change the header to indicate kHz.

If you delete all text from one of the text boxes, the default text will be used when printing the card. In other words, column headers in the QSOs Box are never blank when designing and printing a card.
